questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient with uncontrolled blood sugar levels presents with severe sinus pain, facial swelling, and dark necrotic lesions in the nasal and palatal areas. Imaging reveals sinus opacification and bone destruction. Laboratory tests show elevated blood glucose levels. Which of the following fungal infections is associated with the absence of beta-1,3-D-glucan in its cell wall and is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Mu

Definition

A serious fungal infection caused by Mucorales fungi.

Causative Organisms

Rhizopus, Mucor, and other fungi from the Mucorales order.

Risk Factors

Immunocompromised individuals (e.g., diabetes, organ transplant, chemotherapy), trauma, burns, malnutrition.

Routes of Infection

Inhalation, ingestion, or inoculation of spores through broken skin.

Clinical Forms

Rhinocerebral, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, cutaneous, and disseminated.

Symptoms

Varies depending on the form but can include fever, headache, facial pain, nasal discharge, black eschars, cough, chest pain, abdominal pain, skin lesions.

Diagnosis

Clinical evaluation, imaging (e.g., CT scan), culture, histopathology, PCR.

Treatment

Antifungal medications (e.g., amphotericin B), surgical debridement, control of underlying conditions.

Prognosis

Depends on early diagnosis and treatment; can be severe or fatal if not promptly managed.

Prevention

Controlling underlying conditions, good wound care, and minimizing exposure to environmental sources.

questions.text: Match the following: A Fregoli syndrome 1 Physical duplicate B Syndrome of intermetamorphosis 2 Physical appearance of people remain same Acknowledgement+ C Syndrome of subjective doubles 3 Physical and psychological identity of people change D Capgras syndrome 4 Physical appearance of people change Acknowledgement+
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - A - 4, B - 3, C - 1, D - 2:

A

Fregoli syndrome

4

Physical appearance of people change

Acknowledgement+

B

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis

3

Physical and psychological identity of people change

C

Syndrome of subjective doubles

1

Physical duplicate

D

Capgras syndrome

2

Physical appearance of people remain same

Acknowledgement+

Delusions of Misidentification

Syndrome

Description

Characteristic Belief

Capgras Syndrome

In Capgras Syndrome, the person believes that someone closely related to them has been replaced by an exact double. There is acknowledgment of this change.
  • Belief that a close person has been replaced by a stranger who looks identical. An argument may arise with the close person.

Fregoli Syndrome

Fregoli Syndrome entails the belief that a familiar person is posing as a stranger and can take on multiple appearances. There is acknowledgment of these changing appearances.
  • Belief that a familiar person is pretending to be a stranger and can take on various appearances. An argument may occur with strangers.

Syndrome of Intermetamorphosis

In this syndrome, individuals believe that others undergo changes in both physical and psychological identities, turning into entirely different people.
  • Belief that people are transforming into entirely different individuals in both physical and psychological aspects.

Syndrome of Subjective Doubles

This syndrome involves the delusional belief in the existence of physical duplicates of oneself, living in different parts of the world.
  • Belief in the existence of physical duplicates of oneself residing in different locations around the world.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male patient visits the clinic with a chief complaint of an itchy, scaly, and patchy rash affecting his scalp. Correct Option D - 

Type of Tinea Capitis

Most common causative organisms

Clinical Features

Based on invasion of fungus

Endothrix

Trichophyton tonsurans
  • Broken hair with a "black dot" appearance
  • Gray patch, kerion, or seborrheic-like presentation
  • Often affects African and African-American individuals

Ectothrix

Microsporum canis, Microsporum audouinii Microsporum ferrugineum
  • Broken hairs with spores on the outside
  • Gray patch, black dot, or favus presentation
  • Commonly seen in non-African populations

Based on clinical presentation

Favus

Trichophyton schoenleinii
  • Yellow, cup-shaped crusts (scutula) on the scalp
  • Hair loss, thickened, disfigured nails, and localized pustules
  • Wood lamp examination + with dull green fluorescence

Grey Patch

M. canis

  • Grayish appearance due to broken-off hairs
  • Wood lamp examination + with bright green fluorescence

Kerion

T. ferrugineum

T. verrucosum

  • May be mistaken for a bacterial infection
  • Wood lamp examination negative

Black Dot

T. tonsurans , T. violaceous and T. sondenes
  • Broken hairs with black dots at the base
  • Irregular patches of hair loss
  • Wood lamp examination negative

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine types provide the longest duration of protection?
questions.correct_answer: C. Subunit, recombinant, or conjugate vaccines
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C  - Subunit, recombinant, or conjugate v

Vaccine Type

Mechanism of Action

Live attenuated
  • Uses a weakened form of the virus or bacteria to stimulate an immune response.
  •  Examples
    • MMR
    •  Varicella
    • Yellow fever vaccines.

Inactivated
  • Uses a killed form of the virus or bacteria to stimulate an immune response.
  • Examples
    • Polio
    • Hepatitis A
    • Rabies vaccines.

Subunit, recombinant, or conjugate
  • Uses only specific parts of the virus or bacteria to stimulate an immune response.
  • Examples
    • HPV
    • Pneumococcal
    • Meningococcal vaccines.

mRNA
  • Uses a small piece of genetic material to instruct cells to produce a protein that triggers an immune response.
  • Examples
    • COVID-19 vaccines developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna.

Vector
  • Uses a harmless virus or bacteria to deliver genetic material that instructs cells to produce a protein that triggers an immune response.
  • Examples
    • COVID-19 vaccines developed by AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents to a primary care clinic with a significant weight loss, intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted body image. She reports restricting her food intake drastically and engaging in excessive exercise. She has not menstruated for the past six months. Her BMI is 16.5. Which of the following is a potential consequence seen during nutritional rehabilitation of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Hypophosph

Anorexia Nervosa
  • More common in females (F:M ratio 10:1).
  • Age of onset: 14 to 18 years.

Clinical Features
  • Restriction of energy intake resulting in low body weight.
  • Intense fear of weight gain or obesity.
  • Disturbance of body image.
  • Amenorrhea (formerly necessary but not a current diagnostic criterion).
  • Peculiar behaviors about food.
  • Delayed sexual development.
  • Medical complications secondary to starvation, including hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and more.

Endocrine Changes
  • Decreased LH, FSH, Estrogen, Testosterone, T3, T4.
  • Increased Reverse T3, Cortisol.
  • Normal TSH.

Types of Anorexia Nervosa

1. Binge Eating

  • Intake of large amounts of food in a short duration.
  • Associated with lack of self-control.

2. Purging

  • Patients may perform compensatory methods for excess calorie intake, including vomiting, use of laxatives, diuretics, or emetics.
  • May do excessive exercises.

Comorbid Psychiatric Disorders
  • Most common: Depression.
  • Others: Social phobia, OCD.

Treatment
  • Patients are often secretive and may deny their symptoms.
  • Hospitalization may be needed for restoring nutritional status and managing complications such as dehydration and electrolyte imbalances (↓Na, ↓K, ↓Cl).
  • Treatment goals include nutritional rehabilitation and weight restoration, with gradual caloric increase:

At start 1500-1800 Kcal/day (divided meals)

↓

Gradually increased to 3500-4000 Kcal/day

  • Psychotherapy (behavioural management, individual therapy, and family education) and pharmacotherapy (SSRIs, antipsychotics like Olanzapine) can be beneficial.

Refeeding Syndrome
  • Occurs if carbohydrates and sodium are reintroduced too rapidly, leading to electrolyte imbalances and complications.

If carbohydrates and sodium are reintroduced too rapidly.

↓

↑sed insulin secretion (Anti-natriuretic effect) and ↑ sodium leads to - ↑ECF volume

Carbohydrates

↓

Stimulates intracellular Glucose-6-phosphate and Glycogen synthesis

↓

↓ Phosphate

More intake of food than prior

↓

↑ Metabolism (↓ Phosphate, ↓K, ↓Mg)

 

  • Thiamine deficiency and cardiac arrhythmias may occur.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent episodes of hemoglobinuria, primarily occurring at night. He reports dark urine in the morning and feeling fatigued during the day. On further evaluation, it is found that the patient has a defect in the PIGA gene. Which of the following proteins is affected by this mutation, leading to his clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - 

Condition

Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Gene Mutation

PIGA gene mutation

Protein Affected

Phosphatidylinositol Glycan A (PIGA)

Protein Function

Synthesizes GPI-anchored glycoproteins

GPI-Anchored Glycoproteins

DAF/CD55 and CD59

Function of GPI-Anchored Glycoproteins

Accelerate the decay of C3 convertase

C3 Convertase Function

Prevents the formation of membrane attack complex

Membrane Attack Complex (MAC) Formation

Result of complement pathway activation

Complement Pathways
  • Classical (initiated by antigen-antibody complex)
  • Alternate (triggered by factors like acidic pH)

RBC Hemolysis Occurrence

At night due to low respiration, leading to acidic pH

Protection Mechanism in Normal Individuals

Functionally active DAF/CD55 and CD59, which accelerate C3 convertase decay, protecting RBCs

PNH Pathophysiology

Defective PIGA gene leads to improper GPI anchorage between CD55 and CD59, resulting in C3 convertase not being decayed, leading to RBC lysis in acidic pH at night

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic by concerned parents who noticed a bulging fontanelle on their child's head. The baby appears irritable, and the parents report that the baby has been vomiting excessively. On physical examination, the anterior fontanelle is noticeably tense and bulging. There are no signs of trauma. What is the most likely cause of the bulging fontanelle in this clinical scenario?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Mening

Fontanelle

Timing of Closure

Related Pathologies

Anterior Fontanelle

Typically closes between 12 to 24 months
  • Normal closure: Indicates healthy skull development.
  • Delayed closure: Can be due to nutritional deficiencies or underlying conditions.
  • Bulging Fontanelle: Could indicate increased intracranial pressure, as seen in meningitis or hydrocephalus.

Posterior Fontanelle

Usually closes by 2 to 3 months of age
  • Normal closure: Indicates appropriate skull bone development.
  • Persistent Fontanelle: Rare condition where the posterior fontanelle doesn't close completely. It might be associated with certain genetic disorders.

Sphenoidal Fontanelle

(Anterolateral fontanelle)

Usually closes during the first year of life
  • Normal closure: Indicates proper skull bone formation.
  • Abnormalities: Rarely mentioned in clinical context; abnormal closure might be linked to specific craniosynostosis syndromes.

Mastoid Fontanelle

(Posterolateral fontanelle:)

Usually closes by 6 to 18 months of age
  • Normal closure: Reflects healthy development of the mastoid bone.
  • Abnormalities: Uncommonly discussed in clinical scenarios; abnormal closure could be linked to specific craniosynostosis disorders.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department after using a substance by nodding. He reports a history of rhinorrhea, and upon examination, you notice a jet-black tongue and some scratch marks over his arms. His vital signs include a heart rate of 119 bpm and blood pressure of 156/90 mm Hg. Furthermore, you observe that his pupils are dilated. What is the mechanism of action of the substance most likely responsible for these symptoms?

options.label: D
options.text: Reuptake inhibition of dopamine and norepinephrine

questions.correct_answer: D. Reuptake inhibition of dopamine and norepinephrine
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Reuptake inhibition of dopamine and norepineph

 

COCAINE

Mechanism of Action
  • Cocaine is a potent psychostimulant that primarily acts by inhibiting the reuptake of neurotransmitters, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin in the synapses of the central nervous system (CNS). This leads to increased levels of these neurotransmitters, resulting in intense euphoria and heightened arousal.

Methods of Use
  • Intranasal: Snorting powdered cocaine through the nasal passages.
  • Intravenous: Dissolving cocaine and injecting it into the bloodstream.
  • Smoking: Vaporizing cocaine, typically in a crack form, and inhaling the fumes.
  • Oral ingestion is rare due to limited bioavailability.

Adverse Effects
  • Short-term effects: Euphoria, increased alertness, heightened energy, dilated pupils, decreased appetite, increased heart rate, and elevated blood pressure.
  • Long-term effects: Risk of addiction, cardiovascular issues (e.g., heart attack, stroke), respiratory problems, anxiety, paranoia, and damage to the nasal passages when snorted.

Intoxication Signs and Symptoms
  • Agitation, tremors, anxiety, restlessness, dilated pupils, increased heart rate, elevated blood pressure, hyperthermia, hallucinations, and even seizures in severe cases.

Withdrawal Symptoms
  • Dysphoria (anxiety, depression)
  • Fatigue
  • Increased appetite
  • Disturbed sleep
  • Cravings for cocaine

Cocaine-Induced Psychotic Disorders
  • Prolonged or heavy cocaine use can lead to psychotic symptoms, such as delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized thinking.

Medical Treatment
  • The management of cocaine intoxication and withdrawal typically involves supportive care to address specific symptoms, including benzodiazepines for agitation and seizures. For severe intoxication or complications, hospitalization may be required.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of itching, redness, and peeling of the skin between his toes. He mentions that these symptoms worsen when his feet get sweaty or after playing sports. On examination, you observe erythema and maceration between the toes, and there's a slightly foul odor. What is the most likely causative organism of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Trichophyton rubru

Causative Organism

Trichophyton rubrum, a dermatophyte fungus.

Infection Type

Dermatophytosis, commonly referred to as ringworm.

Clinical Forms

Tinea pedis (athlete's foot), tinea corporis (ringworm), tinea cruris (jock itch), tinea unguium (onychomycosis).

Symptoms

Itchy, red, scaly, and often circular skin lesions, nail changes in onychomycosis.

Transmission

Direct contact with infected humans or contaminated objects like towels, floors, or shoes.

Diagnosis

Clinical examination, microscopic examination of skin scrapings or nail clippings, fungal culture, polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

Treatment

Topical or oral antifungal medications, good hygiene practices, keeping the affected area clean and dry.

Prevention

Practicing good hygiene, avoiding sharing personal items, wearing clean and breathable clothing, keeping skin dry.

Common Sites Affected

Feet, body (especially trunk and limbs), groin, nails.

Prevalence

Common, especially in warm and humid climates.

questions.text: Which opioid among the following acts as an agonist for kappa receptors and a partial agonist for µ receptors?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - P

Aspect

Kappa (κ) Receptors

Mu (µ) Receptors

Location

Mainly in the brain and spinal cord

Predominantly in the brain and spinal cord

Effects

Analgesia, sedation, dysphoria, and diuresis

Powerful analgesia, respiratory depression, euphoria, and physical dependence

Activation

Activation produces analgesia and sedation, but with less potential for abuse

Activation leads to potent analgesia, sedation, and high abuse potential

Endorphin Binding

Binds endorphins with moderate affinity

Binds endorphins with high affinity

Side Effects

Less respiratory depression and constipation

Higher respiratory depression and constipation, higher potential for addiction

Clinical Use

Used in research and as potential analgesics

Common target for opioid pain medications, also involved in addiction potential

Tolerance

Develops more slowly compared to mu receptors

Develops relatively quickly, leading to dose escalation

Withdrawal

Generally milder withdrawal symptoms

Withdrawal symptoms can be severe and debilitating

questions.text: In a 45-year-old woman with low hemoglobin levels and abnormal mitochondrial morphology on muscle biopsy, which component of the electron transport chain is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Complex IV

Component

Function

Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase)

Transfers electrons from NADH to ubiquinone (CoQ)

Complex II (Succinate dehydrogenase)

Part of both the TCA cycle and ETC, transfers electrons from succinate to CoQ

Complex III (Cytochrome bc1 complex)

Transfers electrons from CoQ to cytochrome c

Complex IV (Cytochrome c oxidase)

Transfers electrons from cytochrome c to oxygen (O2), facilitates ATP production

Complex V (ATP synthase)

Generates ATP through oxidative phosphorylation by utilizing the proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male with chest pain, hypertension, and a history of smoking, who presents with diaphoresis and elevated blood pressure, and is diagnosed with an acute myocardial infarction, what is the specific selectin targeted by the antiplatelet agent administered during percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - P

Selectin

Location

Function

E-Selectin
  • Endothelium
  • Mediates leukocyte rolling and adhesion to endothelium. Activated by cytokines, such as TNF-α and IL-1.
  • It also binds to Sialyl Lewis X.

P-Selectin
  • Platelets, Endothelium, Weibel-Palade bodies
  • Mediates leukocyte rolling and adhesion, as well as platelet aggregation. Stored in platelets and endothelial cells. Activated by histamine and thrombin.

L-Selectin
  • Leukocytes
  • Mediates leukocyte rolling and adhesion to endothelium. Important in lymphocyte homing to lymph nodes.
  • It binds to Glycam/Madcam/CD34.

questions.text: Match the following medical device with its appropriate use: 1. a. Used for esophagogastric tamponade therapy . 2. b. Used for treatment of bleeding gastric varices. 3. c. Used for drainage of the common bile duct after choledochotomy 4. d. Used for decompression of the stomach and to control bleeding from esophageal varices.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A

Medical Device

Description

Common Use

Sengstaken Tube

A gastric tube with multiple lumens, including one for gastric aspiration and others for inflation of balloons in the esophagus and stomach.

Used for compression of esophageal varices, controlling bleeding, and gastric decompression.

Kehr's T Tube

A T-shaped drainage tube commonly used after choledochotomy (surgery on the common bile duct).

Used for drainage of the common bile duct to facilitate the flow of bile after gallbladder or bile duct surgery.

Linton Nachlas Tube

A tube used for drainage of the peritoneal cavity, often employed postoperatively or in cases of ascites.

Used for draining excess fluid or pus from the peritoneal cavity, helping prevent infection and promote healing.

Minnesota Tube

A device used for monitoring intra-abdominal pressure and drainage of ascitic fluid in patients with liver disease.

Used in patients with liver cirrhosis and ascites to monitor abdominal pressure and drain excess fluid from the abdomen.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)?

options.label: A
options.text: OCD is more prevalent in children and adolescents, with an estimated 2-3% of the pediatric population affected.

options.label: B
options.text: The most common co-morbidity associated with OCD is depression

options.label: C
options.text: Symmetry/ordering is the second most common obsession/compulsion

options.label: D
options.text: SSRIs are the drug of choice for OCD

questions.correct_answer: C. Symmetry/ordering is the second most common obsession/compulsion
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Symmetry/ordering is the second most common obsession/compu

Treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD):

Pharmacotherapy
  • 1st line: SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors), with preferred agents like fluoxetine, sertraline, or fluvoxamine.
  • Clomipramine, a serotonin-selective tricyclic antidepressant, can also be used. - Augmenting agents: Antipsychotics such as Risperidone, Aripiprazole, Haloperidol, Olanzapine.
  • Other drugs: Valproate, Lithium, Carbamazepine, Lamotrigine, Venlafaxine.

Psychotherapy
  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is the primary psychotherapy approach.
  • Behavioral technique: Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) involves exposing the patient to feared situations and preventing them from engaging in compulsive responses.
  • Other therapies may include desensitization, thought-stopping, flooding, aversive conditioning, psychodynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy.

Other Somatic Therapies
  • In extreme cases that are treatment-resistant, options like Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) and psychosurgery can be considered.

Psychological Procedures
  • Subcaudate tractotomy targets the substatia innominata, white matter tracts connecting the orbitofrontal cortex and subcortical structures.
  • Anterior cingulotomy targets the anterior cingulate cortex.
  • Limbic leukotomy combines elements of subcaudate tractotomy and anterior cingulotomy.
  • Anterior capsulotomy or GAMMA Knife capsulotomy targets the anterior limb of the internal capsule.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in image below:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Uterine Didelph

 

Uterine Didelphys

Definition

A congenital uterine anomaly characterized by the presence of two separate uterine cavities, each with its own cervix, due to incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts during fetal development.

Incidence

Rare, occurring in approximately 0.3% of women.

Etiology

Congenital; results from embryological development during the first trimester when the Müllerian ducts fail to fully fuse, leading to the formation of two uterine structures.

Types

Uterine Didelphys can be categorized into two main types:

Complete (two fully formed uterine structures)

Incomplete (one complete uterus and one rudimentary horn or uterine horn)

Clinical Presentation

Some individuals may be asymptomatic, while others may experience menstrual abnormalities, pelvic pain, recurrent urinary tract infections, and difficulty with sexual intercourse due to the presence of a vaginal septum.

Diagnosis

Typically diagnosed through imaging studies, including pelvic ultrasound, hysterosalpingogram (HSG), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), or hysteroscopy. Physical examination may reveal the presence of two cervixes.

Treatment

Surgical intervention may be considered in cases where there are reproductive difficulties, such as removing a vaginal septum, correcting uterine anomalies, or repositioning a breech-presenting fetus. Fertility treatments or assisted reproductive technologies (ART) may also be used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old individual presents with recurrent, painful, and inflamed lumps in the axillary and groin areas. These lumps often progress to abscess formation and drainage of purulent material. The patient also reports discomfort during physical activities and tight clothing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Acne Inv

 

Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS)/ Acne Inversa/ Prickly heat (Miliaria Crystallina)

Site

Axilla, groin, mammary, umbilicus

Age Group

Pubertal age group

Predisposing Factors
  • Obesity
  • Smoking
  • Diabetes (DM)
  • Insulin resistance
  • Metabolic syndrome

Associations

 
  • Follicular occlusion triad (HS, acne conglobata, dissecting cellulitis of scalp)
  • Tetrad: Follicular occlusion triad + Pilonidal sinus
  • Crohn's disease

Criteria for Diagnosis
  • Typical lesions: Deep-seated painful nodules, abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars, and paired or multiheaded open pseudocomedones

  • Release of debris, including keratin fibers and commensal flora, cytokine-induced inflammation

Exogenous Factors
  • Smoking
  • Obesity
  • Mechanical friction
  • Microorganisms

Pathophysiology

Treatment

  • Weight reduction and diet modifications
  • Smoking cessation
  • Analgesics (for pain)
  • Antibiotics (e.g., Doxycycline, Clindamycin)
  • Anti-inflammatory agents (e.g., Dapsone)
  • Retinoids
  • Biologicals (e.g., Adalimumab, a TNF inhibitor)
  • Surgical therapy (if HS is recurrent)

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a history of recurrent, unexplained, and severe symptoms that have led to multiple hospitalizations and extensive medical workups. She provides a detailed account of her symptoms, including episodes of seizures, palpitations, and severe abdominal pain. She adamantly insists on multiple diagnostic tests and requests several specific medications. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's behaviour?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Pseudolog

Factitious Disorder Imposed on Self (FDIS)

Definition

Factitious Disorder Imposed on Self (FDIS) is characterized by the deliberate feigning, exaggeration, or induction of physical or psychological symptoms to assume the "sick role" and receive medical attention and treatment. The individual creates a complex web of deceit to maintain the illusion of illness or injury.

Also known as
  • Munchausen Syndrome: Named after Baron Munchausen, a fictional character known for telling exaggerated and fantastical stories.
  • Hospital Addiction: Refers to the pattern of frequent hospitalizations and seeking medical care.
  • Professional Patient Syndrome: Individuals may develop extensive knowledge of medical terminology and procedures.
  • Pseudologia Fantastica: Describes the extreme and pathological lying often associated with this condition.

Motivation

The primary motivation is to assume the "sick role" and receive medical attention, treatment, and medications. The individual often craves the emotional gratification and validation associated with being a patient.

Characteristics
  • Feigning or exaggerating symptoms (e.g., physical pain, neurological symptoms, mental health issues).
  • Elaborate and convincing medical histories.
  • Willingness to undergo invasive tests and procedures.
  • Frequent hospital admissions under various names.
  • Resistance to psychiatric evaluation and treatment.

Deceptive Behavior

Individuals may engage in extensive deception, such as fabricating symptoms, manipulating medical records, using false identities, and even inducing illness or injury.

Psychological Factors
  • Motivation is typically internal, driven by the desire to be in the patient role.
  • Often linked to underlying psychological distress, trauma, or personality disorders.

Treatment
  • Difficult to treat due to the individual's reluctance to acknowledge the deception.
  • Psychotherapy, particularly inpatient or residential programs, may be necessary.
  • Addressing underlying psychological issues is crucial.
  • Monitoring and limiting unnecessary medical interventions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with severe eye pain and redness. On examination, you note a tender, inflamed, and raised area on the white part of the eye. The patient reports that the pain worsens with eye movement and is associated with headaches. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical findings, and what is the characteristic feature of this condition seen in the affected eye?

options.label: A
options.text: Conjunctivitis; Presence of discharge and itching

options.label: B
options.text: Corneal abrasion; Visible defect on the corneal surface

options.label: C
options.text: Scleritis; Blue or violaceous discoloration of the sclera

options.label: D
options.text: Retinal detachment; Flashes of light and floaters

questions.correct_answer: C. Scleritis; Blue or violaceous discoloration of the sclera
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C- Scleritis; Blue or violaceous discoloration of th

Clinical Features of Scleritis

Description

Eye Pain

Severe, deep, boring, or throbbing pain that is often worse at night and may radiate to the head.

Redness

Diffuse, intense redness of the sclera that does not blanch with topical vasoconstrictors.

Photophobia

Sensitivity to light, making it uncomfortable for the patient to be in bright environments.

Tenderness on Palpation

The affected area of the sclera is tender to touch and may feel nodular or raised upon examination.

Decreased Visual Acuity

Blurred vision or decreased vision can occur, especially if the cornea or deeper structures are involved.

Episcleritis vs. Scleritis

Episcleritis typically involves only the episclera, is more benign, and may cause milder symptoms. Scleritis is a more severe condition affecting the deeper scleral layers.

Systemic Associations

Scleritis can be associated with systemic diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, vasculitis, or inflammatory bowel disease. It may require a systemic workup.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with abdominal cramps and profuse, watery diarrhea after consuming a meal at a local restaurant. The symptoms developed within hours, and the patient reports nausea and low-grade fever. Stool examination shows leukocytes and red blood cells. Which diagnostic finding is most consistent with E. coli infection in this patient?

Correct Option A - Presence of fecal leuk

Diagnostic Finding

Details

Stool Culture

Identification of E. coli strains in stool samples.

PCR Testing

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for detecting E. coli DNA in clinical samples.

Serologic Tests

Detecting antibodies against specific E. coli antigens.

Complete Blood Count (CBC)

May show leukocytosis (increased white blood cell count) if there's an associated infection or inflammation.

Urinalysis

If the infection is uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC), urinalysis may reveal white blood cells, red blood cells, and bacteria in urine.

Clinical Evaluation

Based on symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever.

Imaging Studies

In some cases, imaging like abdominal X-rays or CT scans may be performed to assess complications like kidney involvement or obstruction.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with redness, tearing, and discharge in both eyes. On examination, you notice bilateral conjunctival infection and watery discharge. The child's parents report that other children in the school have similar symptoms. What is the most likely key pathophysiological mechanism involved in this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Viral invasion and replication in conjunctival cells

options.label: D
options.text: Exposure to irritants or foreign bodies

questions.correct_answer: C. Viral invasion and replication in conjunctival cells
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C- Viral invasion and replication in conjunctiv

Clinical Features of Conjunctivitis

Description

Eye Redness

Conjunctivitis often presents with red or pink discoloration of the white part of the eye (sclera).

Discharge

Depending on the type of conjunctivitis, discharge may be watery, mucous, or purulent (yellow or green).

Itching and Irritation

Patients often report itching, burning, or a gritty sensation in the eyes.

Tearing

Excessive tearing or tearing in response to light (photophobia) can be a symptom, especially in viral or allergic conjunctivitis.

Foreign Body Sensation

Some patients may feel as if there is a foreign body in the eye, contributing to discomfort.

Crusting of Eyelids

In the morning, eyelids may be stuck together due to discharge crusting.

Swelling of the Eyelids

Swelling of the eyelids, especially in bacterial or allergic conjunctivitis.

Infection Duration

The duration of symptoms can vary from acute (a few days) to chronic (lasting weeks to months).

Transmission

Infectious conjunctivitis may be highly contagious and easily transmitted through contact with contaminated hands or objects.

Watery Discharge in Allergic Conjunctivitis

Allergic conjunctivitis often presents with clear, watery discharge and is associated with allergic rhinitis.

Purulent Discharge in Bacterial Conjunctivitis

Bacterial conjunctivitis can produce purulent, yellow or greenish discharge and is highly contagious.

Follicles in Viral Conjunctivitis

Viral conjunctivitis may exhibit small, raised bumps (follicles) on the conjunctiva.

Allergic Conjunctivitis Triggers

Triggers include pollen, dust mites, pet dander, and other allergens.

Bacterial Conjunctivitis Causative Bacteria

Common causative bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Haemophilus influenzae.

Viral Conjunctivitis Causative Viruses

Viral agents include adenoviruses, herpes simplex virus, and others.

questions.text: A 32-year-old HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 150 presents with confusion, headache, and fever. Imaging studies reveal multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the brain. The patient is not on any prophylactic treatment for opportunistic infections. What is the most common complication of toxoplasmosis in immunocompromised individuals, as seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D

Aspect

Details

Causative Agent

Toxoplasma gondii, an intracellular parasite.

Transmission

Ingestion of oocysts from cat feces, consumption of undercooked or contaminated meat, organ transplantation, and congenital transmission from mother to fetus.

Clinical Forms

Acute (fever, lymphadenopathy), congenital (from mother to fetus), ocular (retinochoroiditis), and reactivated toxoplasmosis in immunocompromised individuals.

Symptoms

Can range from asymptomatic to flu-like symptoms in acute cases, ocular issues in ocular toxoplasmosis, and severe issues in congenital or immunocompromised individuals.

Diagnosis

Serology (detecting antibodies, IgM and IgG), polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and occasionally biopsy or culture for confirmation.

Treatment

Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine, sometimes with folinic acid (leucovorin), are commonly used.

Prevention

Avoiding consumption of undercooked meat, practicing good hygiene, and minimizing contact with cat feces.

Complications

Neurological and ocular complications in severe cases.

Congenital Infection Risks

Higher risk during pregnancy if the mother acquires a primary infection.

Prevalence

Worldwide distribution; prevalence can vary by region and population.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient with a history of thyrotoxicosis presents to the clinic for evaluation. He reports episodes of frequent urination and is concerned about elevated glucose levels in his urine. On examination, the patient's thyroid function is within normal limits, and his blood glucose levels are well-controlled. However, he continues to experience glycosuria. Which of the following best explains the glycosuria in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired insulin secretion due to pancreatic dysfunction

options.label: C
options.text: Alimentary glycosuria related to upregulation of Glut transporters

options.label: D
options.text: Renal tubular disorders affecting glucose reabsorption

questions.correct_answer: C. Alimentary glycosuria related to upregulation of Glut transporters
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Alimentary glycosuria related to upregulation of Glu

Reducing Sugars

Causes

Glucose

Renal threshold of glucose= 180 mg/dL
  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Renal glycosuria
    • Damage in proximal convoluted tubules (PCT)- Reabsorb all glucose filtered by glomeruli.
    • Eg. Fanconi syndrome
  • Alimentary glycosuria:
    • Increase in rate of absorption of glucose along the intestine.
    • In the immediate postprandial state, there will be a steep increase in plasma glucose.
    • Beta cells release insulin due to the steep increase.
    • When insulin is released, there is not much of an increase in plasma glucose because all the intestinal glucose is already entered into the plasma.
    • This leads to a steep fall in glucose levels.
    • In GTT (glucose tolerance test), when there is a steep rise (hyperglycemia) and steep fall (hypoglycemia) and in an immediate postprandial state, a steep rise crosses the renal threshold found in urine, indicating alimentary glycosuria.
    • Causes: Thyrotoxicosis (thyroxine causes upregulation of Glu transporters across enterocytes).

Fructose
  • Essential fructosuria
    • Defect of fructokinase enzyme
  • Hereditary fructose intolerance
    • Caused by aldolase D defect

Galactose
  • Galactosemia
    • Deficiency in galactokinase
  • Classical Galactosemia
    • Defect of GalPUT (galactose 1 phosphate uridylyl transferase.

Pentose
  • Essential Pentosuria

options.label: B
options.text: Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2

options.label: C
options.text: Diphtheria toxin is carried in the bloodstream to target distant organs

options.label: D
options.text: Local infection in the respiratory tract can lead to the formation of a pseudomembrane

questions.correct_answer: C. Diphtheria toxin is carried in the bloodstream to target distant organs
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Diphtheria toxin is carried in the bloodstream to target distant org

Causative Agent

Corynebacterium diphtheriae, a bacterium.

Mechanism of Action

The bacterium produces diphtheria toxin, an exotoxin.

Diphtheria Toxin

- Inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2).
- Forms a pseudomembrane in the throat.

Pseudomembrane

A thick, grayish-white membrane in the throat, composed of dead cells, bacteria, and fibrin.

Local Effects

The pseudomembrane can obstruct the airway and lead to respiratory distress.

Systemic Effects

Diphtheria toxin can enter the bloodstream and affect distant organs, causing myocarditis and nerve damage.

Transmission

Spread through respiratory droplets, direct contact with skin lesions, or fomites.

Vaccination

Diphtheria toxoid is part of the DTP or DTaP vaccines, preventing diphtheria.

Treatment

Antitoxin to neutralize the circulating toxin and antibiotics to eliminate the bacterium.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a complaint of decreased vision in the right eye. On examination, you note that the patient's right eye has an afferent pupillary defect. Additionally, fundus examination reveals optic disc pallor in the right eye. Which structure in the order of the optic pathway is most likely affected in this patient's right eye, leading to the observed clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B- Optic nerv

Component/Structure of the Optic Pathway

Description

Retina

The process begins with the absorption of light by photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) in the retina.

Optic Nerve (Cranial Nerve II)

The optic nerve is composed of retinal ganglion cell axons. It carries visual information from the retina to the brain.

Optic Chiasm

At the optic chiasm, some fibers from each optic nerve cross over to the opposite side, while others continue on the same side.

Optic Tract

After the chiasm, the nerve fibers form the optic tract, which carries visual information further into the brain.

Lateral Geniculate Nucleus (LGN)

The optic tract fibers synapse in the LGN of the thalamus.

Optic Radiation

From the LGN, the visual pathway continues as optic radiation fibers, which extend to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.

Primary Visual Cortex

The primary visual cortex, located in the occipital lobe, processes and interprets visual information received from the optic pathway.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of glaucoma presents for a follow-up visit. The intraocular pressure (IOP) is well-controlled with medications, and the patient reports good compliance with the prescribed eye drops. However, the patient mentions a recent decrease in vision and the appearance of halos around lights, especially at night. On examination, you note a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.8 in both eyes and the optic nerve head appears pale. What is the most likely complication of glaucoma in this patient that is responsible for the decreased vision and the appearance of halos around lights, and what is the key pathophysiological mechanism underlying this complication?

options.label: B
options.text: Retinal detachment; Traction on the retina

options.label: D
options.text: Optic neuropathy; Progressive damage to the optic nerve

questions.correct_answer: D. Optic neuropathy; Progressive damage to the optic nerve
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D- Optic neuropathy; Progressive damage to the optic nerv

Aspect of Glaucoma Pathophysiology

Description

Intraocular Pressure (IOP)

Elevated IOP is a major risk factor for glaucoma. Increased IOP can result from the impaired drainage of aqueous humor or increased production of aqueous humor.

Aqueous Humor Drainage

In open-angle glaucoma, there is decreased drainage of aqueous humor from the trabecular meshwork. In angle-closure glaucoma, the angle between the iris and cornea becomes blocked, causing a sudden increase in IOP.

Optic Nerve Damage

Elevated IOP can exert pressure on the optic nerve, leading to damage. This damage typically starts with the loss of peripheral vision.

Retinal Ganglion Cell Loss

Retinal ganglion cells are susceptible to glaucomatous damage. Their apoptosis leads to visual field defects.

Cupping of the Optic Disc

Increased pressure within the eye can cause the excavation of the optic disc, resulting in an increased cup-to-disc ratio.

Vision Impairment and Blindness

If left untreated, glaucoma can lead to irreversible vision loss, progressing from peripheral vision loss (scotomas) to total blindness.

Risk Factors

Age, family history, high IOP, thin central corneal thickness, and certain systemic conditions are common risk factors for glaucoma.

Treatment

Glaucoma management often involves reducing IOP with medications, laser therapy, or surgical procedures. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding collagen synthesis is incorrect? Collagen is the most abundant protein in the extracellular matrix, providing tensile strength to tissues. Collagen synthesis occurs mainly in fibroblasts and chondrocytes, specialized connective tissue cells. Collagen type I is most abundant in bone, tendons, skin, and dentin. Collagen type II is primarily found in hyaline cartilage and the vitreous humor of the eye. Collagen synthesis involves hydroxylation of proline and lysine for stability. Collagen is secreted without post-translational modifications
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - The incorrect statements in the giv

Collagen

Collagen Definition

A family of structural proteins found in the extracellular matrix of tissues, providing strength and support.

Collagen Synthesis

Occurs primarily within specialized connective tissue cells like fibroblasts and chondrocytes.

Post-Translational Modification

Involves the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues, which is essential for collagen stability and proper formation.

Types of Collagen

Collagen Type I

Most abundant type, found in bone, tendons, skin, and dentin. Provides tensile strength.

Collagen Type II

Mainly found in hyaline cartilage and intervertebral discs. Provides structural support to cartilaginous tissues.

Collagen Type III

Commonly found in reticular fibers and organs like the liver and spleen. Provides structural support and elasticity.

Collagen Type IV

A major component of basement membranes, found in various tissues, including the kidney glomerulus.

Collagen Type V

Often found in association with type I collagen, playing a role in regulating collagen fibrillogenesis.

Collagen Type VII

Anchors collagen fibrils to basement membranes, important for skin integrity.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with a sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing. On examination, you notice inflamed tonsils with white or yellow patches and swollen cervical lymph nodes. The patient complains of a headache and abdominal pain. What is the most likely causative organism of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes)

Clinical Feature

Description

Sore Throat

Pharyngitis, often with a red, inflamed throat.

Fever

Elevated body temperature as part of the immune response.

Swollen Tonsils

Enlarged and inflamed tonsils, especially in Group A Streptococcus infections (strep throat).

White Patches

White or yellow patches on the throat, tonsils, or oral mucosa, indicating infection.

Redness and Inflammation

Redness and swelling of the affected area, such as the throat.

Difficulty Swallowing

Pain and discomfort when swallowing.

Cough

A persistent cough, especially in cases of post-streptococcal complications.

Skin Rash

In streptococcal infections like scarlet fever or impetigo, a characteristic rash may develop.

Lymphadenopathy

Swollen and tender lymph nodes in the neck (cervical lymphadenopathy).

Fever

Elevated body temperature as part of the immune response.

Complications

Potential complications include rheumatic fever, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, and more.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of frequent eye rubbing and long-term contact lens wear presents with complaints of gradual vision deterioration in both eyes. On examination, you observe that the patient has a history of keratoconus, a type of corneal ectasia. Visual acuity testing reveals significant astigmatism. Corneal topography shows corneal thinning and steepening, and the patient reports experiencing monocular diplopia (double vision) when looking at distant objects. What is the likely cause of monocular diplopia in this patient with keratoconus, and how does the corneal ectasia lead to this visual disturbance?

options.label: A
options.text: Lens dislocation; Forward displacement of the lens

options.label: B
options.text: Corneal scarring; Opacity and irregularity of the cornea

options.label: C
options.text: Irregular astigmatism; Distortion of light entering the eye

options.label: D
options.text: Macular degeneration; Damage to the macula

questions.correct_answer: C. Irregular astigmatism; Distortion of light entering the eye
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C- Irregular astigmatism; Distortion of light entering th

Aspect of Keratoconus

Description

Definition

Keratoconus is a progressive eye disorder characterized by the thinning and bulging of the cornea into a cone-like shape.

Prevalence

Keratoconus typically starts in the late teens to early twenties and may progress over a few years. It can affect both eyes but usually starts in one eye.

Etiology

The exact cause is unknown, but genetic factors and eye rubbing are common contributors.

Clinical Features
  • Irregular astigmatism, causing blurred and distorted vision.
  • Increased myopia (nearsightedness) and astigmatism.
  • Frequent changes in eyeglass or contact lens prescriptions.
  • Corneal thinning, leading to cone-shaped bulging.
  • Vision distortion, glare, and photophobia.

Diagnosis
  • Corneal topography to map the corneal surface.
  • Slit-lamp examination to assess corneal shape.
  • Pachymetry to measure corneal thickness.
  • Visual acuity and refraction tests.

Treatment
  • Early stages: Eyeglasses or soft contact lenses.
  • Moderate stages: Rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lenses for better corneal support.
  • Advanced stages: Corneal cross-linking to strengthen the cornea.
  • Severe stages: Corneal transplant (keratoplasty) for vision improvement.

Progression

The progression of keratoconus varies, but in some cases, it may stabilize in the 30s or 40s. Regular follow-up is essential to monitor progression.

Complications
  • Scarring of the cornea, impacting vision.
  • Hydrops, a sudden corneal swelling due to a tear in the cornea.
  • Reduced quality of life, especially if vision correction methods are inadequate.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a 20-year history of heavy smoking has sought assistance to quit smoking. The healthcare provider decides to initiate varenicline for smoking cessation. The standard dosing regimen for varenicline involves gradual titration over several days. On which day of varenicline treatment is the patient typically instructed to take the maintenance dose of 1 mg twice daily?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - D

Treatment for Smoking Cessation

5 A's for Helping Smoking Cessation
  • Ask: Inquire whether the individual consumes tobacco.
  • Advice: Provide firm advice to quit smoking.
  • Assess: Evaluate the individual's willingness to quit smoking.
  • Assist: Offer support and assistance to help with quitting.
  • Arrange: Schedule follow-up contact to monitor progress and provide further support.

Pharmacological Treatment
  • Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT):
  • Used to manage withdrawal symptoms by replacing tobacco nicotine with safer forms of nicotine.
  • Forms of NRT include nicotine gums, lozenges, patches, nasal spray, and inhalers.
  • Non-Nicotine Medications:
  • Varenicline: A partial agonist at α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. It reduces dopamine release and smoking reinforcement. Dosing schedule:
  • Days 1-3: 0.5 mg once daily
  • Days 4-7: 0.5 mg twice daily
  • Day 8 onwards: 1 mg twice daily
  • Maintenance of abstinence: Some patients may continue Varenicline for up to 3 months.
  • Common adverse effects: nausea, insomnia, headache.
  • Serious adverse effects: neuropsychiatric (depression, suicidal ideation) and cardiovascular effects (for patients with cardiovascular diseases).
  • Bupropion: An antidepressant acting as a Norepinephrine Dopamine Reuptake Inhibitor (NDRI). Common adverse effects include insomnia and nausea. It may also have neuropsychiatric adverse effects, and caution is needed for patients with a history of seizure disorders or eating disorders.

Psychotherapy
  • Behavioral Therapy: Behavioral therapy, particularly in the form of behavior modification, is widely accepted for treating tobacco use disorders. It focuses on changing behaviors and developing strategies to quit smoking.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presents with complaints of progressive vision blurriness and glare when driving at night. On examination, you observe clouding of the eye's natural lens and a decrease in visual acuity. Pupil dilation reveals opacities in the lens of both eyes. What type of cataract is most likely affecting this patient, and what is the key characteristic of this type of cataract that leads to glare and vision blurriness, especially in bright light or while driving at night?

options.label: A
options.text: Nuclear cataract; Increased lens nuclear sclerosis

options.label: C
options.text: Subcapsular cataract; Opacities near the posterior capsule

questions.correct_answer: A. Nuclear cataract; Increased lens nuclear sclerosis
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A- Nuclear cataract; Increased lens nu

Aspect of Nuclear Cataract

Description

Definition

Nuclear cataract is a type of age-related cataract characterized by the opacification of the central (nuclear) portion of the eye's natural lens.

Prevalence

Nuclear cataracts are the most common type of age-related cataracts, and they tend to develop gradually with aging.

Etiology
  • Primarily related to aging and cumulative oxidative damage to lens proteins.
  • Other factors include genetics, smoking, and ultraviolet light exposure.

Clinical Features
  • Gradual worsening of vision, especially with reading and near tasks.
  • Difficulty seeing in bright light or while driving at night (glare).
  • Improvement in near vision without glasses (second sight).
  • Changes in the perception of color (dull or yellowish vision).

Diagnosis
  • Slit-lamp examination for evaluating lens opacities.
  • Visual acuity tests to assess the impact on vision.
  • Dilated eye examination for a detailed view of lens changes.

Treatment
  • In early stages, vision may be improved with updated eyeglass prescriptions.
  • As the cataract progresses, cataract surgery (phacoemulsification) is usually required.
  • During surgery, the opacified lens is removed and replaced with an intraocular lens.

Progression

Nuclear cataracts tend to progress slowly and can eventually lead to significant visual impairment if left untreated.

Prevention

Protective measures include wearing sunglasses to reduce UV exposure, avoiding smoking, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.

Complications

If untreated, nuclear cataracts can lead to decreased visual quality, difficulty performing daily tasks, and an increased risk of accidents.

questions.text: A 25-year-old otherwise healthy individual presents with a painful, recurrent oral ulcer with vesicular lesions on the lip. The patient suspects that it's a recurrence of a previously diagnosed herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 infection. What is the first step in the management of this patient's recurrent HSV type 1 infection?

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribe antibiotics for secondary bacterial infection

questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Recommend warm saline

Causative Virus

Herpes Simplex Virus type 1 (HSV-1).

Clinical Presentation

Oral herpes (cold sores), genital herpes, and occasionally ocular or systemic infections.

Transmission

Direct contact with oral or genital lesions or contact with infected saliva or genital secretions.

Primary Symptoms

Painful oral or genital ulcers, fever, lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms during initial infection.

Recurrent Infections

Outbreaks of ulcers and blisters at or near the site of the initial infection, often triggered by stress, illness, or UV exposure.

Latency

HSV-1 can establish latency in sensory nerve ganglia, leading to recurrent outbreaks.

Diagnosis

Clinical evaluation, viral culture, PCR testing, and serological tests for antibodies.

Treatment

Antiviral medications (e.g., acyclovir, valacyclovir) to manage symptoms and reduce transmission.

Prevention

Safe sex practices, avoiding direct contact with active lesions, and vaccination when available.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a localized skin infection characterized by a red, swollen area with pus-filled lesions. The patient has a history of recurrent skin infections and reports tenderness and warmth at the site. The clinical presentation is consistent with a staphylococcus infection. questions.correct_answer: B. Incision and drainage of abscesses, followed by culture and sensitivity testing
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Incision and drainage of abscesses, followed by culture and sensitivity testing

Causative Bacteria

Staphylococcus species, commonly Staphylococcus aureus.

Clinical Presentations

Various infections, including skin and soft tissue infections, pneumonia, septicemia, endocarditis, and more.

Transmission

Direct contact with infected individuals, contaminated surfaces, or fomites.

Common Skin Infections

Impetigo, folliculitis, boils, cellulitis, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

Antibiotic Resistance

Staphylococcus aureus strains, including MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus), may be resistant to many antibiotics.

Virulence Factors

Toxins, including exotoxins, coagulase, and superantigens; cell surface adhesins; and resistance mechanisms.

Diagnosis

Clinical evaluation, culture and sensitivity testing, PCR, and serological tests.

Treatment

Antibiotics, depending on the specific strain and antibiotic susceptibility; incision and drainage for abscesses.

Prevention

Good hygiene, handwashing, wound care, and infection control practices in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a chronic cough, night sweats, weight loss, and hemoptysis. He reports a history of working in a healthcare setting where he was exposed to patients with tuberculosis (TB). A chest X-ray reveals apical lung infiltrates, and a sputum sample is collected. Which laboratory finding is typically expected in the sputum sample of a patient with active pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Aspect

Details

Causative Agent

Mycobacterium tuberculosis, an acid-fast bacillus.

Transmission

Airborne transmission through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes.

Clinical Presentation

- Pulmonary TB: Primary and reactivation TB affects the lungs, causing cough, fever, and hemoptysis.

- Extra-pulmonary TB: Affects other organs, such as lymph nodes, bones, and the central nervous system.

Latent TB Infection (LTBI)

Asymptomatic infection without clinical symptoms; diagnosed through positive tuberculin skin or blood tests.

Granuloma Formation

Infected macrophages form granulomas to contain the bacteria, which can calcify.

Mycobacterial Cell Wall

Thick, waxy cell wall rich in mycolic acids; provides resistance to host immune responses and antibiotics.

Acid-Fast Staining

Used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis due to its resistance to decolorization with acid and alcohol.

Ziehl-Neelsen Stain

A red stain used for acid-fast staining, making TB bacilli appear red against a blue background.

Culture and Sensitivity

Sputum and other samples can be cultured for M. tuberculosis, and sensitivity testing helps determine appropriate antibiotics.

Diagnosis

Chest X-rays, sputum smears and cultures, interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs), and tuberculin skin tests (TSTs).

Treatment

Multidrug therapy with isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide for at least six months.

Prevention

BCG vaccine (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) in some regions, respiratory hygiene, and treatment of active cases.

Drug-Resistant TB

Emergence of multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) and extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB) due to inadequate treatment and poor adherence.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats is being evaluated for a possible respiratory infection. The patient has no known exposure to tuberculosis. Sputum samples are collected for analysis. In sputum samples obtained from this patient, acid-fast staining is performed. What color do acid-fast bacilli (AFB) appear when stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen or Kinyoun method?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - R

Staining Method

Principle

Application

Gram Stain

Differential staining based on cell wall composition.

Distinguishes bacteria into Gram-positive (purple) and Gram-negative (pink) based on cell wall properties.

Acid-Fast Stain

Differentiates acid-fast bacteria with thick, waxy cell walls.

Used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis and other acid-fast bacilli.

Ziehl-Neelsen Stain

A type of acid-fast stain using red dye for acid-fast bacteria.

Identifies tuberculosis and leprosy bacilli.

Capsule Stain

Detects the presence of protective capsules around bacterial cells.

Useful for identifying pathogens like Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Endospore Stain

Highlights the presence of endospores, a type of dormant bacterial structure.

Identifies bacteria like Clostridium and Bacillus species.

Flagella Stain

Enhances the visibility of bacterial flagella, used for motility.

Useful in studying bacterial movement.

Negative Stain

Stains the background, leaving bacterial cells colorless.

Used for observing capsules, cell size, and morphology.

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E)

A combination stain used in histology to differentiate cell components.

Commonly used in tissue and cell microscopy.

Methylene Blue Stain

A general stain used to visualize bacterial cells and nuclei.

Simple and widely used for basic microscopy.

Crystal Violet Stain

A basic stain that imparts a purple color to bacterial cells.

Often used in Gram staining and simple staining techniques.

Safranin Stain

A counterstain in Gram staining, used to color Gram-negative bacteria.

Completes the Gram staining process.

Indian Ink Stain

A negative stain used for visualizing capsules of certain bacteria.

Especially useful for identifying Cryptococcus neoformans.

questions.text: Which of the following post-transcriptional modifications of the RNA given in picture primarily occur in the nucleus?

options.label: B
options.text: Rearrangement of glycosidic linkages to create pseudouridine

questions.correct_answer: B. Rearrangement of glycosidic linkages to create pseudouridine
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Rearrangement of glycosidic linkages to create pseudou

Step

Description

1. Transcription
  • tRNA has its own gene, leading to a primary transcript.

2. Shape Transformation
  • Initially, it's in a simple straight chain form.
  • It attains a cloverleaf shape due to intra-chain base pairing.

3. First Modification
  • Formation of pseudouridine from uridine.

4. Second Modification
  • Rearrangement of glycosidic linkages to create pseudouridine.

5. Third Modification
  • Conversion of adenosine to inosine.

6. Fourth Modification
  • Random methylation of specific bases.

7. Fifth Modification
  • Random alkylation of specific bases.

8. Nucleus-Cytoplasm Transition
  • Post-transcriptional modifications (steps 1-5) occur in the nucleus.

9. Truncation and Attachment
  • Truncated tRNA is not attached to the CCA triplet nucleotide.
  • Nucleotidyl transferase adds CCA triplet nucleotide to the tRNA.
  • This modification occurs in the cytoplasm.

10. Functionalization
  • Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases attach the specific amino acid to tRNA.
  • This process completes the functionalization of tRNA.

Gel Filtration Chromatography (size-based), Ion Exchange Chromatography (charge-based)

Steps

Description

Paper Size & Preparation

Whatman paper is cut to size and a reference line is drawn.

Application of Sample

Amino acid mixture is applied to the paper at a reference point.

Solvent Preparation

A solvent (n-butanol, acetic acid, water) is used in the petri dish.

Separation Mechanism

Based on polarity, nonpolar amino acids move faster.

Result

Amino acids separate based on their polarity.

Key Feature

Process occurs on a flat surface.

Type

Principle of Separation

Example

Gel Filtration Chromatography

Separation based on size

Separation of proteins based on size.

Ion Exchange Chromatography

Separation based on charge

Cation Exchange (for cations), Anion Exchange (for anions)

Cation Exchange Chromatography

Used for cation separation

Separates proteins with cationic properties.

Anion Exchange Chromatography

Used for anion separation

Separates proteins with anionic properties.

Separation Mechanism

Gel filtration: Smaller proteins are trapped in pores, while larger ones pass through. Ion exchange: Protein charge interacts with stationary phase charge.

 

Elution Process

Elution with appropriate buffer to release retained proteins.

 

Examples

Carboxymethyl sepharose (Cation Exchange), Diethylaminoethyl (DEAE) (Anion Exchange)

 

Common Application

Cation Exchange is widely used for HbA1c estimation.

Correct Option D - Sitagliptin promotes degradation of GLP

Long-term Management of Type 1 DM

Carbohydrate counting

- Regulate carbohydrate intake

- 1 unit of lispro neutralizes 15g of Carbohydrates

- Insulin supplementation

Insulin Supplementation

Subcutaneous route (SC)

- Injection sites:

  • Anterior abdominal wall (2cm from umbilicus)
  • Arm
  • Anterolateral aspect of thigh
  • Buttock

- Avoid dorsum of the hand

Insulin Delivery

Insulin Pump: - Mimics artificial pancreas - Microprocessor device - Continuous SC insulin infusion - Releases basal insulin continuously - Bolus insulin delivery at mealtimes - High cost - Insulin Pen (31 G): - Painless and bloodless insulin delivery - Inhaled Insulin (Afreeza / Exubera) - Multidose Vial with 1ml syringe - Longest acting insulin: Degludec (42 hours) - Insulin calculated as 50% basal, 50% prandial.

Diet Control

Regulate carbohydrate intake - Emphasize low glycemic index foods: oats, multigrain bread, egg whites, brown rice, white meat, and multigrain atta - Use fats like butter/ghee and PUFA like safflower oil - Avoid trans fats.

Exercise

Increases GLUT4 receptors

- Promotes sugar entry into muscles, lowering blood sugar levels

- Recommended: 30 minutes of jogging 5 days per week (150 minutes per week).

Oral Hypoglycemic Drugs

Control HbA1C - Consider the following oral hypoglycemic drug categories:

- Biguanides (e.g., Metformin, Phenformin)

- Sulfonylureas (e.g., Tolbutamide, Glibenclamide)

- Thiazolidinones (e.g., Pioglitazone, Rosiglitazone)

- α-Glucosidase Inhibitors (e.g., Acarbose, Voglibose, Miglitol)

- Meglitinides (e.g., Repaglinide, Nateglinide)

- Dipeptidyl Peptidase-4 Inhibitors (e.g., Linagliptin, Sitagliptin)

- Incretins (e.g., Exenatide, Liraglutide)

- SGLT-2 Inhibitors (e.g., Canagliflozin)

- Drugs used in both Type 1 and Type 2 DM: Pramlintide, Acarbose, insulin.

Diet Control

Regulate carbohydrate intake

- Emphasize low glycemic index foods: oats, multigrain bread, egg whites, brown rice, white meat, and multigrain atta

- Use fats like butter/ghee and PUFA like safflower oil

- Avoid trans fats.

Exercise

Increases GLUT4 receptors

- Promotes sugar entry into muscles, lowering blood sugar levels

- Recommended: 30 minutes of jogging 5 days per week (150 minutes per week).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true for a 35-year-old patient with recurrent, itchy, blistering skin rashes on extensor surfaces, gastrointestinal symptoms after wheat consumption, granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, and elevated tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies?

options.label: A
options.text: The skin lesions are primarily due to an allergic reaction to gluten in the diet.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies is indicative of a diagnosis of dermatitis herpetiformis alone.

options.label: C
options.text: IgG deposits in the skin are typically seen in this patient's condition.

options.label: D
options.text: The most likely HLA haplotype associated with this condition is HLA-DQ2

questions.correct_answer: D. The most likely HLA haplotype associated with this condition is HLA-DQ2
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - The most likely HLA haplotype associated with this condition is HLA-DQ2

Aspect

Celiac Disease

Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Definition

An autoimmune gastrointestinal disorder triggered by the consumption of gluten, resulting in damage to the small intestine.

A chronic autoimmune skin condition closely associated with celiac disease. It presents with intensely itchy, blistering skin rashes.

Common Symptoms

Gastrointestinal symptoms such as bloating, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and malabsorption.

Itchy, blistering skin rashes, typically on extensor surfaces (elbows, buttocks).

Pathogenesis

Autoimmune response to gluten (found in wheat, rye, and barley) causing damage to the small intestine's lining.

Autoimmune response to gluten (same as celiac disease) but manifests in the skin.

Immune Mechanism

Involves both cellular and humoral immune responses.

IgA and complement deposition in the dermal papillae of the skin.

Diagnosis

Blood tests for anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and anti-endomysial antibodies, followed by endoscopy with duodenal biopsy to confirm small intestine damage.

Skin biopsy showing IgA deposits in the dermal papillae; sometimes blood tests for anti-tTG antibodies.

HLA Association

Strongly associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 haplotypes.

Strongly associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 haplotypes, same as celiac disease.

Treatment

Lifelong adherence to a gluten-free diet to manage symptoms and prevent complications.

Lifelong adherence to a gluten-free diet to manage symptoms and skin manifestations.

Complications

Potential complications include nutritional deficiencies, osteoporosis, and increased risk of certain cancers.

Potential complications include the same as celiac disease, along with skin-related issues.

Relationship

Dermatitis herpetiformis is considered the skin manifestation of celiac disease.

Often referred to as the "skin version" of celiac disease. Many individuals with DH also have underlying celiac disease.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to a history of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds. The boy's maternal grandfather had similar symptoms throughout his life. The family history also reveals that the boy's maternal uncle passed away in early childhood due to severe bleeding after minor injuries. The patient's parents, who are both healthy, are concerned about his health and potential bleeding disorder. What is the most likely mode of inheritance for this young boy's condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - 

Inheritance pattern

Description

Examples

Autosomal Dominant

One mutated allele causes the disease

Each affected person usually has one affected parent

Appears in every generation of an affected family (Vertical)

Marfan syndrome; Achondroplasia; Huntington disease; Myotonic dystrophy

Autosomal Recessive

Two mutated alleles needed to cause the disease

Parents are usually unaffected heterozygotes

Not typically seen in every generation (Horizontal).

Beta thalassemia; Cystic fibrosis; Homocystinuria

X-Iinked Dominant

Females are more frequently affected than males

No male-to-male transmission

Rett syndrome; Hypophosphatemia

X-Iinked Recessive

Males are more frequently affected than females

Both parents of an affected daughter must be carriers

Fathers cannot pass X-linked traits to their sons

Haemophilia; Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

Mitochondrial

Only females can pass on mitochondrial conditions to their children (maternal inheritance)

Both males and females can be affected

Can appear in every generation of a family

LHON: Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate is brought to the pediatric clinic by concerned parents. The baby was born full-term and appeared healthy at birth. However, in the past 24 hours, the parents have noticed that the infant's skin and eyes have developed a yellowish discoloration. The parents have also observed abnormal movements in the baby's limbs. On further assessment, it was discovered that the baby's maternal aunt experienced similar symptoms of jaundice and abnormal movements in her childhood, which eventually improved. What is the most likely part of the brain involved in this neonate's condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Basal gang

 

Acute Bilirubin Encephalopathy

Chronic Bilirubin Encephalopathy

Onset

Rapid onset, typically in the first few days of life.

Gradual onset, developing over a longer period.

Associated Conditions

Occurs in the presence of severe neonatal jaundice.

May occur in the setting of longstanding jaundice.

Bilirubin Levels

Elevated serum bilirubin levels.

Elevated serum bilirubin levels.

Clinical Features

Presents with acute neurological symptoms such as irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, hypoactivity, high-pitched cry, arching of the back, seizures, and decreased muscle tone.

Presents with more chronic neurological symptoms, which may include delayed developmental milestones, muscle hypertonia, muscle stiffness (hypertonia), and developmental delays.

Brain Injury

Acute brain injury due to the toxic effects of unconjugated bilirubin on the central nervous system.

Chronic brain injury, often resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of unconjugated bilirubin.

Kernicterus Risk

Kernicterus is a severe form of acute bilirubin encephalopathy.

Kernicterus may be seen in the context of chronic bilirubin encephalopathy.

Treatment

Immediate treatment with phototherapy and exchange transfusion to reduce bilirubin levels.

Treatment may involve long-term management of the underlying cause, such as hemolysis or liver disease.

Developmental Domain

Milestones

Gross Motor

In ventral suspension:

  • Lifts head and chest (2 months)
  • Supports weight on forearms (3 months)
  • Rolls over (5-6 months)
  • Sits without support (6-8 months)
  • Crawls (8-10 months)
  • Stands with support (9-12 months)
  • Walks independently (12-15 months)

 

In prone position:

  • Lifts head briefly (1 month)
  • Lifts head steadily (2 months)
  • Supports upper body with forearms (2-4 months)
  • Rolls from back to side (4-6 months)
  • Rolls from front to back (5-7 months)
  • Sits independently (6-7 months)
  • Stands with support (6-7 months)
  • Walks around furniture (9-10 months)

Fine Motor
  • 15 months: Scribbles spontaneously, feeds self with a cup, makes a tower of 2 cubes
  • 18 months: Builds a tower of 3 cubes, feeds self with a spoon, turns 2-3 pages at a time, unzips
  • 2 years: Creates a tower of 6-7 cubes, makes a train with blocks, turns a doorknob or unscrews a lid, turns pages singly, wears socks and shoes
  • 2.5 years: Builds a train with a chimney
  • 3 years: Handedness gets established (appears at 24 months and established at 36 months), constructs a tower of 9-10 cubes, can dress/undress self except buttons
  • 4 years: Constructs a bridge with cubes, buttons and unbuttons, catches a ball reliably
  • 5 years: Ties shoelaces, builds a gate with cubes, skips rope
  • 6-7 years: Copies a diamond, constructs steps with cubes

questions.text: A newborn infant is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit with respiratory distress shortly after birth. A chest X-ray revels the following : Based on the chest X-ray image and clinical presentation, which genetic predisposition is most commonly associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)? 1 Down syndrome 2 Turner syndrome 3 Patau syndrome 4 Edwards syndrome
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - 3,4

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

A diaphragmatic defect through which abdominal contents may herniate into the thorax along with pulmonary hypoplasia and Intestinal malrotation

  • Common Type : Postero-lateral or Bochdalek variety
  • Most common on the left side
  • More common in females

Other Defects Associated With
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Congenital heart diseases
  • Omphalocele
  • Trisomy 13, 18

Clinical Features

At birth, usually presents with a triad of:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Scaphoid abdomen (abdominal contents go into the thorax)
  • Mediastinal shift

 

Later in Life

Intestinal obstruction (due to associated malrotation)

Diagnosis
  • Clinical features
  • Antenatal ultrasound (between 16-24 weeks)
  • Chest X-Ray
  • Bowel gas shadows in the thorax
  • Mediastinal shift
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia

Treatment

 

Bag and mask ventilation is absolutely contraindicated in CDH.

Important Predictors of Poor Outcome
  • Severe pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Lung head ratio (LHR) < 1
  • Any major malformation associated
  • Symptoms in 1st 24 hours
  • Liver herniation into thorax
  • Need of ECMO

Most Common Cause of Mortality

Pulmonary complications/hypoplasia

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for a surgical procedure under general anesthesia. The anesthesia team decided to use a depolarizing muscle relaxant as part of the anesthesia induction process. Following the administration of succinylcholine, the patient quickly develops paralysis and undergoes intubation. However, a few minutes after the administration, the patient starts experiencing muscle fasciculations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of muscle fasciculations following the use of succinylcholine, and how should it be managed?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypothermia; Warm intravenous fluids should be administered.

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperkalemia; Administer calcium gluconate and initiate measures to lower potassium levels.

options.label: C
options.text: Respiratory acidosis; Increase the ventilator settings to improve ventilation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Hyperkalemia; Administer calcium gluconate and initiate measures to lower potassium levels.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B- Hyperkalemia; Administer calcium gluconate and initiate measures to lower potassium lev

Side Effect/Adverse Reaction

Description

Fasciculations

Initial muscle twitches or contractions, often observed following succinylcholine administration.

Hyperkalemia

Elevated levels of potassium in the blood, which can lead to life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.

Increased Intracranial Pressure

May occur in patients with head injuries or intracranial pathology, potentially leading to elevated pressure within the skull.

Malignant Hyperthermia

Rare but life-threatening reaction to succinylcholine, leading to severe muscle rigidity, high fever, and potentially fatal complications.

Muscle Pain

Discomfort or pain in the muscles after succinylcholine administration.

Myalgias

Muscular pain, often in the lower back, following succinylcholine use.

Bradycardia

A slower-than-normal heart rate, which may occur, especially in pediatric patients.

Hypersensitivity Reactions

Allergic responses such as rash, hives, itching, and, rarely, anaphylaxis.

Prolonged Paralysis

Some individuals may experience prolonged muscle paralysis due to genetic variations in their cholinesterase enzymes.
